Picasa
intro.elements:
Well, hello.

I'm Jenny. I build software, currently focusing on health care, always aiming to make users' daily lives better. I live in Cambridge (the American one) and work at athenahealth.

My skills

I work as a full-stack software engineer with user experience design skills. I'm most fluent in Perl and PHP; I've also worked in Python, Ruby on Rails, Java, and ActionScript. I'm quite comfortable with SQL, with 6+ years of experience.

On the presentation side of things, I'm proficient from the basics of HTML to CSS to JavaScript, including jQuery, LESS, Backbone, and Mustache. My technical work is informed by experience with interaction design, visual design, and user experience research.

Why 'orange'?

Tangerines, pumpkins, and apricots - what's not to love? Also, it's easier for visitors to spell than a domain name based on 'Schweers' would have been.

sections.title: Recent Projects
sections.detail: I currently work at athenahealth, doing feature development for athenaClinicals. Outside of work, lately it's been web applications based in Perl and Rails.

elements.name: athenahealth
elements.detail:
I currently work as a senior software engineer at athenahealth, which uses software as a service to make health care better: electronic health records (EHRs), practice management, and patient communication.

My mission has been to improve athenaClinicals, our EHR, most frequently from a user experience perspective: redesigning core workflows; improving provider productivity; and supporting Meaningful Use. Due to the proprietary nature of this work, unfortunately, I cannot provide significant detail.

elements.name: Flavors
elements.detail: An interface to my music collection, Flavors organizes songs and collections based on personal metadata and uses this information to generate personally meaningful playlists.

gallery.name: Collections
gallery.detail: Songs are grouped into collections of alnums or personal mixes.

gallery.name: Categories
gallery.detail: Flavors is based off of user-specific metadata, so it includes several pages that facilitate the input of this data, aiming to make the process less tedious.

gallery.name: Lab
gallery.detail: In the lab, playlists are generated based off of songs' similarity to an initial seed song. The user configures the definition of similarity: one might bump up the importance played by a song's energy level or by the mood it elicits.

elements.name: Workouts
elements.detail: A project to track my running, rowing, and other activities. Gave me a reason to brush up on Rails and play with Flot.

elements.name: You Win...Now What?
elements.detail: A JavaScript-based game I put together in a weekend at the Purple Monkey Game Jame.

sections.title: Past Projects
sections.detail: Before joining athena, I studied information and interaction design at Carnegie Mellon University, earning a master's degree in human-computer interaction. Prior to this, I worked as a software engineer at eBay. I also hold a bachelor's degree in computer science from Worcester Polytechnic Institute.

elements.name: Flex Keyboard
elements.brief: A simulated piano and sheet music editor
elements.detail: A simulated piano and sheet music editor. Users can play freely using either mouse or keyboard and also record their music. Once recorded, songs can be played back, and the sheet music generated can be edited.

gallery.name: Boston Marathon Visualization
gallery.detail: A visualization of the 2009 Boston Marathon, illustrating how the pack of runners ebbed and flowed over the course of the race. Users can insert themselves into the race, seeing where they would have finished.

gallery.name: Marathon Poster
gallery.detail: A poster to motivate runners training for the San Francisco MarathonTM. It displays a training plan, a sketch of the course, and sights along the way. A graph keeps track of total mileage run throughout the season, putting each week's long run in perspective.

elements.name: eBay: Developer Tools
elements.brief: Projects to improve the developer experience of my team at eBay

gallery.name: Workflows
gallery.detail: This is a system to move intensive web-initiated tasks offline. Each workflow is broken into small, reusable steps. Email notifications keep users up to date on the status of their workflows. Initially, tasks were executed sequentially by a batch job; later, the back-end was integrated with another tool in order to run jobs in parallel. I was responsible for every aspect of this system, which dramatically reduced page load times and browser crashes.

gallery.name: Queue Manager: System Status
gallery.detail: The queue manager is a system that distributes and manages thousands of jobs daily across a pool of worker machines. Redesigning the interface lessened the development team's support load and enabled involvement of a remote support team.

gallery.name: Queue Manager: Batch Detail
gallery.detail: Details of a single batch: job dependencies, batch-level commands, and job-level commands.

elements.name: eBay: Product
elements.brief: Feature development for eBay's Internet Marketing Solutions team
elements.detail: I worked with Internet Marketing Solutions for three years, largely on feature development for the company's ad optimization platform.

gallery.name: Legal Portal
gallery.detail: A tool to tailor an internet marketing application to the needs of the corporate legal team. It enables the legal team to track sensitive keywords and remove them from the live keyword portfolios if necessary, overriding the usual business processes and queueing mechanisms.

gallery.name: Keyword Dashboard
gallery.detail: Interface for internet marketing analysts to investigate interesting keywords. Thousands of keywords are marked as 'interesting' each day by a static query; the dashboard lets users sift through those keywords in a variety of ways and then take action on individual keywords. I designed and implemented the interface, while another team member wrote the scripts to choose and store relevant keywords.

elements.name: Mobile design
elements.detail: Research and design for mobile phone apps.

gallery.name: Tiramisu: Overview
gallery.detail: This mobile application acts as a citizen-powered automatic vehicle location system. I worked on one of several teams designing the interaction for different variations of this system. The application has since been released for the iPhone. The default view displays the user's current location and nearby bus stops.

gallery.name: Tiramisu: Bus Fullness
gallery.detail: Once a user gets on a bus, the app asks how full the bus is, so it can warn waiting users if they might be passed by an overly full bus.

gallery.name: Tiramisu: Trip Details
gallery.detail: After boarding the bus and providing fullness information, the user can leave the app on and allow it to periodically transmit their location to the central server. To encourage users to keep it open, the app contains an alarm that will notify the user just before arrival.

gallery.name: FoodForward: Scenario of Use
gallery.detail: A mobile app to facilitate healthy food choices and strengthen family connections. FoodForward helps users select foods, accounting for nutrition, individual health conditions, environmental concerns, and personal preference. Design was driven in part by the creation of a persona and relevant scenarios of her day.

gallery.name: FoodForward: Wireframes
gallery.detail: Early wireframes of the main screens.

gallery.name: FoodForward: System Map
gallery.detail: A model of all screens in the app and their functions.

elements.name: Site design
elements.detail: Projects completed as part of my master's in human-computer interaction. These focused on user research, information architecture, and wireframing, although one also included building a Python-run, MySQL-backed prototype.

gallery.name: AIR Information Architecture
gallery.detail: A seven-month project to redesign the website of the American Institutes for Research (AIR), with a semester of user research followed by a semester of design and prototyping. This was a team of four, with me acting as technical lead. Our new information architecture simplified the site's structure, moving from two main navigation menus to one and eliminating duplicate content that plagued the original site.

gallery.name: AIR Homepage
gallery.detail: The homepage of our final design centers on a tabbed pane introducing AIR's five focus areas. It also features recent content and a rotating employee.

gallery.name: Soirée Overview
gallery.detail: Soirée is an online meal preparation tool to help chefs at any experience level execute a complex event. The front page of Soirée outlines the 3-step process—select, prepare, and cook—and displays a few mouthwatering recipe ideas.

gallery.name: Soir&eactue;e: Cooking
gallery.detail: To support the actual cooking, Soirée generates a Gantt-style chart outlining which steps to take when, accounting for the available equipment, the user's skills, and the final meal time.

gallery.name: BusBuzz
gallery.detail: A website for commuters to provide feedback about public buses. My team was tasked with conducting contextual inquiries to learn about user needs, producing a set of wireframes, and running thinkaloud usability tests on our design.

gallery.name: Parley: Overview
gallery.detail: Parley is a public interactive system designed to initiate and mediate conversations. Participants each have a "conversation space" projected on an interactive floor. A central cylinder allows users to investigate likely topics for conversation, populated by current events, SMS messages sent to the system, and, optionally, information from participants' public online profiles.

gallery.name: Happy Feet
gallery.detail: Assignment was to investigate the nature of a 20' x20' x 20' public space and then design an installation relating to the space's qualities and the 2009 G-20 Summit in Pittsburgh. We designed a way for passerby to express their opinions about changes in their quality of life, based on the concept of Gross National Happiness.

gallery.name: Invertebrate Zoology
gallery.detail: A poster to attract attention for the Invertebrate Zoology Department at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History.

gallery.name: The Aeron
gallery.detail: A brochure to advertise the Aeron office chair.

gallery.name: Minestrone Soup
gallery.detail: A soup recipe.

gallery.name: I'm Craving Something...
gallery.detail: A book of appetizer recipes, themed around the cravings each recipe satisfies.

elements.name: Front Loader Bed
elements.detail: Building a bed shaped like a front loader.

gallery.name: Model
gallery.detail: A scale model of the final bed. The blueprints, acquired from Plans4Wood, were intended for a child's bed, with little space between the mattress and the roof. I redesigned the blueprints, adjusting them to raise the roof so that I would be able to sit up in bed.

gallery.name: Supplies
gallery.detail: Four sheets of birch, one sheet of plywood, and a 2 x 4.

gallery.name: Details
gallery.detail: The roof and assorted decorative pieces.

gallery.name: Final Assembly
gallery.detail: The bed would be too large to fit through a doorway, so it had to be built in the room where it would be used. Unfortunately, this also meant it had to be dismantled when I moved out.

gallery.name: Back Half
gallery.detail: The back half of the bed, complete.
